text: I think the one one of the major
challenges of uh any human rights uh
enforcement or process is that whether
you are you you are in some ways uh in
resisting the state apparatus and the
the Journey Begins around that time for
for anybody to recognize that there is
the problem and that the power that is
exercised by the state or in some ways
non-state actors in fact it is no longer
the case that human rights violations
are committed only by state actors there
are a number of non-state actors all
over the world who are engaged in human
rights violations and those could in
some ways be responded through the
criminal law measures but also these
violations continue to happen and it is
important that Civil Society needs to be
mobilized now in societies where where
there is a basic rule of law framework
the legal system is the first sort of uh
mechanism that ought to uh take steps
and of course in these societies uh
developed societies where there is a
sort of a reasonable framework for um
rule of law to be enforced courts are
functional there is a law is upheld uh
you know there is an enforcement
missionary to ensure that the judgments
given by the courts are implemented in
these societies the lawyers role is in
many ways using these institutional
missionary and mechanisms to ensure that
the rights are not violated first place
and if they are violated there is proper
redressal in the form of punishment to
the offenders or compensation or
reparation measures for the victims of
human rights violations now the
challenge becomes even more uh difficult
in those societies where rule of law is
not sufficient protected the courts are
not in sufficiently independent the
media is not uh independent and they
don't have the sort of uh Power to
exercise freedom in a manner that is
prevailing in other societies in those
societies the role of Human Rights
actors is one is more important and two
much more difficult now um if you look
at in countries all over the world there
is when when when societies are more
open and Democratic the challenges of
Human Rights the well let me put it like
this the challenges of human rights in
all these societies are are r large it
is there it's it's one it would be
mistake to say that Democratic societies
have less human rights challenges than
undemocratic societies where the
difference lies is in Democratic
societies there is a method and a
process by which some of these
challenges are actually overcome but in
undemocratic societ ities and
authoritarian societies it is difficult
because any exposure of human rights
violations any attempt to uh you know in
some ways highlight these human rights
violations uh becomes a a threat to the
government and the government perceives
takes in many ways in sometimes actions
against these individuals so Eternal
vigilance on the part of citizenry in
all these societies becomes important
and of course here I would like to
highlight the role of non-governmental
organizations ngos both domestic as well
as International domestic ngos are
important because they are the sort of
conscience of a country within a country
highlighting issues and in some ways
bringing it to the bringing the matters
uh to the public domain for people to
understand International noos are
important because sometimes the
government the domestic ngos are not
heard within the country and if serious
issues of Human Rights violations
happening in one country if it is not if
these domestic actors are not able to
bring it to the uh Limelight the
international noos can bring it to the
knowledge of the International Community
and later countries or if the matter is
serious enough even the United Nations
can take actions against the people
responsible for these human rights
violations so the the the the role of
Human Rights um uh Defenders becomes
very critical in all these situations
